A

A-B Trust

A legal arrangement to divide assets into two trusts (A and B) for tax benefits.

Learn more →

A-Shares

Shares that have voting rights and receive dividends, typically owned by insiders.

Learn more →

AAA

The highest credit rating given by rating agencies, indicating the lowest risk of default.

Learn more →

Ability-to-Pay Taxation

A tax system that considers the taxpayer's ability to pay the tax.

Learn more →

Abnormal Return

The return on an investment that deviates from its expected outcome.

Learn more →

Absolute Return

The return that an asset or portfolio achieves over a certain period.

Learn more →

Accelerated Depreciation

A method that records higher depreciation cost in the early years of an asset's life.

Learn more →

Acceleration Clause

A contract provision that allows a lender to require a borrower to repay all or part of a loan immediately.

Learn more →

Account Balance

The amount of money in a financial repository, such as a checking or savings account, at any given moment.

Learn more →

Account in Trust

A financial account opened by one person for the benefit of another.

Learn more →

Account Number

A unique string of numbers assigned to a customer's account by a financial institution.

Learn more →

Account Statement

A periodic summary of account activity with beginning and ending monetary balances.

Learn more →

Accounting

The process of recording financial transactions pertaining to a business.

Learn more →

Accounting Conservatism

An accounting principle that requires greater verification for positive financial outcomes than negative ones.

Learn more →

Accounting Cycle

The process of recording, processing, summarizing, and reporting an organization's financial transactions.

Learn more →

Accounting Equation

A fundamental equation in double-entry accounting (Assets = Liabilities + Equity).

Learn more →

Accounting Information System (AIS)

A system designed to collect, store, and process financial and accounting data.

Learn more →

Accounting Rate of Return (ARR)

A financial metric used to measure the profitability and feasibility of a project.

Learn more →

Accounting Ratio

A financial metric used to assess a company's financial health by comparing various line items within their financial statements.

Learn more →

Accounts Payable (AP)

Money owed by a business to its suppliers shown as a liability on a company's balance sheet.

Learn more →

Accounts Payable Turnover Ratio

A short-term liquidity measure used to quantify the rate at which a company pays off its suppliers.

Learn more →

Accounts Receivable (AR)

Money owed to a business by its clients shown as an asset on a company's balance sheet.

Learn more →

Accounts Receivable Aging

A report categorizing a company's accounts receivable by the length of time an invoice has been outstanding.

Learn more →

Accounts Receivable Financing

A type of asset-financing arrangement where the company uses its receivables as collateral in a financing agreement.

Learn more →

Accretion

The growth of a company's earnings, assets, or an investment portfolio.

Learn more →

Accretion of Discount

The increase in the value of a discounted instrument as time passes and it matures.

Learn more →

Accrual Accounting

An accounting method that records revenues and expenses when they are incurred, regardless of when cash is exchanged.

Learn more →

Accruals

Revenues or expenses that have been incurred but not yet recorded in the accounts.

Learn more →

Accrued Expense

An expense that a business has incurred but has not yet paid.

Learn more →

Accrued Income

Revenue that has been earned but not yet received.

Learn more →

Accrued Interest

Interest that has been incurred but not yet paid.

Learn more →

Accrued Liability

A financial obligation a company incurs over time but has not yet paid.

Learn more →

Accrued Revenue

Revenue that a company has earned but has not yet billed to its customer.

Learn more →

Accumulated Depreciation

The total depreciation of an asset since its purchase.

Learn more →

Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income

The total of non-operating gains and losses that bypass the income statement.

Learn more →

Accumulation/Distribution Indicator (A/D)

A technical analysis tool that shows cumulative flow of money into and out of a security.

Learn more →

Acid-Test Ratio

A financial metric that assesses a company's short-term liquidity.

Learn more →

Acquisition Accounting

A set of guidelines to report assets, liabilities, non-controlling interest, and goodwill of the acquired entity.

Learn more →

Active Management

An investment strategy that relies on the expertise of portfolio managers to choose investments.

Learn more →

Activity-Based Budgeting (ABB)

A budget system that assigns costs to activities and services measured by the level of activity.

Learn more →

Activity-Based Costing (ABC)

A costing method that identifies activities in a company and assigns the cost of each activity to products and services.

Learn more →

Activity Ratios

Financial metrics that measure a company's ability to convert different accounts within its balance sheets into cash or sales.

Learn more →

Actuarial Gain Or Loss

Changes in the estimated value of future obligations of a pension plan due to differences between actual and expected results.

Learn more →

Ad Valorem Tax

A tax based on the assessed value of an item, such as real estate or personal property.

Learn more →

Add-On Interest

A type of interest that is calculated at the beginning of a loan and added to the principal.

Learn more →

Additional Child Tax Credit

A refundable credit that can be claimed by taxpayers who are ineligible to claim the full non-refundable child tax credit.

Learn more →

Additional Paid-In Capital

Capital received from investors in excess of the par value of shares.

Learn more →

Adjustable-Rate Mortgage (ARM)

A type of mortgage in which the interest rate applied on the outstanding balance varies throughout the life of the loan.

Learn more →

Adjusted Closing Price

A stock's closing price on any given day of trading that has been amended to include any distributions and corporate actions.

Learn more →

Adjusted Funds From Operations (AFFO)

A financial performance measure primarily used in the analysis of real-estate income trusts.

Learn more →

Adjusted Gross Income (AGI)

Gross income minus certain adjustments, used to calculate taxable income.

Learn more →

Adjusted Present Value (APV)

The net present value of a project if financed solely by equity plus the present value of financing benefits.

Learn more →

Adjusting Journal Entry

An entry in financial reporting to correct a mistake made in a previous entry.

Learn more →

Advance Payment

Money that is given before goods or services are provided.

Learn more →

Advanced Internal Rating-Based (AIRB)

An approach under Basel II regulations for calculating risk-weighted assets.

Learn more →

After-Tax Real Rate of Return

The annual percentage return realized on an investment, which is adjusted for changes in prices due to external effects.

Learn more →

After-Tax Contribution

Contribution made to any designated retirement or investment account after taxes have been deducted.

Learn more →

After-Tax Income

The amount of money left over after all federal, state and withholding taxes have been deducted from taxable income.

Learn more →

Aggressive Investment Strategy

A strategy that aims to maximize returns by investing in higher risk assets.

Learn more →

Allocated Loss Adjustment Expenses (ALAE)

Costs directly attributable to the settlement of an insurance claim.

Learn more →

Allowance for Bad Debt

An estimate of the debt that a company is unlikely to recover.

Learn more →

Allowance for Credit Losses

An estimate of the amount of credit sales that are not likely to be collected.

Learn more →

Allowance for Doubtful Accounts

A contra-asset account that offsets the total receivables reported on the balance sheet to reflect only amounts expected to be collected.

Learn more →

Alternative Depreciation System (ADS)

A method of calculating the depreciation of certain types of assets in a manner that spreads the cost over a fixed number of years.

Learn more →

Alternative Investment

An investment in asset classes other than stocks, bonds, and cash.

Learn more →

Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT)

A tax designed to prevent taxpayers from escaping their fair share of tax liability through tax breaks.

Learn more →

Altman Z-Score

A statistical tool used to measure the likelihood of a company going into bankruptcy.

Learn more →

Amended Return

A form filed in order to correct errors in a tax return from a previous year.

Learn more →

American Depositary Receipt (ADR)

A negotiable certificate issued by a U.S. bank representing a specified number of shares in a foreign stock traded on a U.S. exchange.

Learn more →

American Depositary Share (ADS)

A U.S. dollar-denominated equity share of a foreign-based company available for purchase on an American stock exchange.

Learn more →

Amortizable Bond Premium

The excess price paid over the face value of a bond, which can be reduced over time for tax purposes.

Learn more →

Amortized Bond

A bond that is regularly paid off over its lifespan, also known as an installment debt.

Learn more →

Amortized Loan

A loan with scheduled periodic payments of both principal and interest.

Learn more →

Angel Investor

A high net worth individual who provides financial backing for small startups or entrepreneurs.

Learn more →

Annual Equivalent Rate (AER)

A rate that can be compared between financial institutions that calculates interest on an annual basis.

Learn more →

Annual Percentage Rate (APR)

The annual rate charged for borrowing or earned through an investment.

Learn more →

Annual Percentage Yield (APY)

A rate that reflects the total amount of interest paid on an account, based on the interest rate and the frequency of compounding.

Learn more →

Annual Return

The compound average rate of return for a stock, fund or asset per year over a period of time.

Learn more →

Annualized Income

An estimate of the amount of money that an individual or business will earn over a year.

Learn more →

Annualized Rate of Return

The geometric average amount of money earned by an investment each year over a given time period.

Learn more →

Annualized Total Return

The geometric average return of an investment over a given period of time.

Learn more →

Annuity

A financial product that pays out a fixed stream of payments to an individual, primarily used as an income stream for retirees.

Learn more →

Appraisal Costs

The cost of ensuring that products or services are of the required quality.

Learn more →

Appreciation

An increase in the value of an asset over time.

Learn more →

Appropriation Account

A financial statement providing detailed information about the amount of profit retained within a business.

Learn more →

Arbitrage Pricing Theory (APT)

A theory of asset pricing that holds that a security's returns can be predicted using the relationship between its expected return and its systematic risk.

Learn more →

Arbitrageur

An investor who tries to profit from price inefficiencies in a market by making simultaneous trades.

Learn more →

Arm's Length Transaction

A transaction in which the buyers and sellers of a product act independently and without any relationship to each other.

Learn more →

Arms Index (TRIN)

A technical analysis indicator that compares advancing and declining stock issues and trading volume.

Learn more →

Asset Allocation

An investment strategy that aims to balance risk and reward by apportioning a portfolio's assets according to an individual's goals, risk tolerance and investment horizon.

Learn more →

Asset-Backed Security (ABS)

A financial security collateralized by a pool of assets such as loans, leases, credit card debt, royalties or receivables.

Learn more →

Asset-Based Approach

A method of business valuation that focuses on a company's net asset value.

Learn more →

Asset-Based Lending

A business loan secured by collateral.

Learn more →

Asset Coverage Ratio

A financial metric that measures a firm's ability to cover its debt obligations with its assets.

Learn more →

Asset Financing

The use of a company's balance sheet assets to borrow money or get a loan.

Learn more →

Asset/Liability Management

The process of managing the use of assets and cash flows to meet a company's obligations.

Learn more →

Asset Management Company (AMC)

A company that invests its clients' pooled funds into securities matching declared financial objectives.

Learn more →

Asset Swap

An exchange of tangible assets for a set of cash flows.

Learn more →

Asset Swapped Convertible Option Transaction (ASCOT)

A convertible bond separated into its two components: a straight bond and a call option on the stock.

Learn more →

Asset Turnover Ratio

The ratio of the value of a company's sales or revenues relative to the value of its assets.

Learn more →

Asset Valuation

The process of determining the fair market value of assets.

Learn more →

Assumable Mortgage

A type of financing arrangement in which an outstanding mortgage can be transferred from the current homeowner to a buyer.

Learn more →

Assurance

A type of financial coverage that provides remuneration for an event that is certain to happen.

Learn more →

At Par

A term that refers to a bond, preferred stock or other debt obligation that is trading at its face value.

Learn more →

At The Money

An option whose strike price is equal to the market price of the underlying security.

Learn more →

Audit

An independent examination of financial information of any entity to make sure the accounts are a fair and accurate representation.

Learn more →

Automated Clearing House (ACH)

A computer-based electronic network for processing transactions between participating financial institutions.

Learn more →

Automated Customer Account Transfer Service (ACATS)

A system that facilitates the transfer of securities from one trading account to another at a different brokerage firm.

Learn more →

Automated Teller Machine (ATM)

An electronic banking outlet that allows customers to complete basic transactions.

Learn more →

Automatic Bill Payment

A money transfer scheduled on a predetermined date to pay a recurring bill.

Learn more →

Available Balance

The amount of money in a bank account that is currently available for use.

Learn more →

Available-for-Sale Security

A debt or equity security that is purchased with the plan of selling before it reaches maturity.

Learn more →

Average Annual Growth Rate (AAGR)

The average increase in the value of an individual investment or portfolio over a set period of time.

Learn more →

Average Annual Return (AAR)

The arithmetic mean of a series of annual returns.

Learn more →

Average Cost Basis

A method of calculating the value of an investment

Learn more →

Average Daily Balance Method

A method used by credit card companies to calculate the amount of interest charged for a billing period.

Learn more →

Average Outstanding Balance

A balance calculation typically used in credit cards to determine interest charges.

Learn more →

Average Return

The profit or loss made by an investment over a certain period, expressed as a proportion of the initial investment.

Learn more →
B

Baby Bond

A bond with a par value below $1,000.

Learn more →

Backdoor Roth IRA

A method for high-income individuals to bypass income limits by converting a traditional IRA into a Roth IRA.

Learn more →

Backflush Costing

A streamlined cost accounting method that speeds up and simplifies costing by eliminating the tracking of individual costs.

Learn more →

Backup Withholding

The tax that is levied on investment income, at an established tax rate, as the investor withdraws it.

Learn more →

Bad Credit

A description of a person's credit history indicating that they have a low credit score.

Learn more →

Bad Debt

A receivable that a company is unable to collect from a debtor.

Learn more →

Balance of Payments (BOP)

A record of all monetary transactions between a country and the rest of the world.

Learn more →

Balance Sheet

A financial statement that reports a company's assets, liabilities, and shareholders' equity at a specific point in time.

Learn more →

Balanced Fund

An investment fund that combines a stock component, a bond component, and a money market component in a single portfolio.

Learn more →

Balanced Investment Strategy

A portfolio allocation strategy that divides assets into equal parts between aggressive and conservative investments.

Learn more →

Balloon Loan

A loan that features a large, lump-sum payment scheduled at the end of a series of smaller periodic payments.

Learn more →

Balloon Payment

A large payment due at the end of a loan's term to repay the remaining balance.

Learn more →

Bank Capital

The difference between a bank's assets and liabilities.

Learn more →

Bank Credit

The total amount of credit available to a business or individual from a banking institution.

Learn more →

Bank Deposits

Funds placed into a banking institution for safekeeping.

Learn more →

Bank Reserve

The currency deposit that is not lent out to the bank's clients.

Learn more →

Bank Statement

A summary of financial transactions that occurred at a certain bank during a specific time period.

Learn more →

Bank Stress Test

An analysis to determine whether a bank has enough capital to withstand the impact.

Learn more →

Bank-Owned Life Insurance (BOLI)

A form of life insurance purchased by banks where the bank is the beneficiary, and/or owner.

Learn more →

Banker's Acceptance

A short-term debt instrument issued by a firm that is guaranteed by a commercial bank.

Learn more →

Bank Reconciliation

The process by which a company's bank statement is matched to its own accounting records.

Learn more →

Bank Run

A situation where a large number of bank customers withdraw their deposits simultaneously over concerns of the bank's solvency.

Learn more →

Bankruptcy

A legal process in which a person or business declares inability to repay their outstanding debts.

Learn more →

Barbell

An investment strategy that involves purchasing both short-term and long-term bonds, but no intermediate-term bonds.

Learn more →

Bare Trust

A basic trust in which the beneficiary has the absolute right to the capital and assets within the trust.

Learn more →

Base Effect

The distortion in a monthly inflation figure that results from abnormally high or low levels of inflation in the year-ago month.

Learn more →

Base Year

A reference point in time used as a benchmark in financial analysis.

Learn more →

Basic Earnings Per Share (EPS)

A measure of how much profit a company has made per share of its stock.

Learn more →

Basis Point (BPS)

A unit of measure used in finance to describe the percentage change in the value or rate of a financial instrument.

Learn more →

Basis Risk

The risk that the futures price might not move in normal, steady relationship with the underlying cash price.

Learn more →

Basket Trade

A large portfolio of stocks that is purchased with the intention of achieving a similar return to the index.

Learn more →

Bear Market

A condition in which securities prices fall 20% or more.

Learn more →

Bearer Bond

A bond that is owned by the holder, i.e., the person who has possession of the bond.

Learn more →

Behavioral Finance

A field of finance that proposes psychology-based theories to explain stock market anomalies.

Learn more →

Beneficiary

An individual or entity that receives benefits, profits, or advantages from something.

Learn more →

Benefit-Cost Ratio

A ratio used in a cost-benefit analysis to summarize the overall relationship.

Learn more →

Bid

An offer made by an investor, trader, or dealer to buy a security, commodity, or currency.

Learn more →

Billing Cycle

The interval of time from the end of one billing statement date to the next billing statement date.

Learn more →

Binance Coin (BNB)

A cryptocurrency created by Binance, one of the largest cryptocurrency exchanges in the world.

Learn more →

Bitcoin

A digital or virtual currency that uses peer-to-peer technology to facilitate instant payments.

Learn more →

Bitcoin Mining

The process of creating new bitcoins by solving complex mathematical problems.

Learn more →

Bitcoin Wallet

A digital wallet used to store, send, and receive bitcoins.

Learn more →

Black Money

Income illegally obtained or not declared for tax purposes.

Learn more →

Black Scholes Model

A model for estimating the value of a stock option.

Learn more →

Blended Rate

A weighted average interest rate of two or more loans.

Learn more →

Blind Trust

A trust where the beneficiaries have no knowledge of the holdings of the trust.

Learn more →

Block Trade

A large trade, typically a large number of shares of a stock or bonds.

Learn more →

Blockchain

A decentralized and distributed digital ledger technology.

Learn more →

Blockchain-as-a-Service (BaaS)

A cloud service that enables users to build digital products working with blockchain.

Learn more →

Blockchain Wallet

A digital wallet allowing users to manage bitcoin and Ethereum.

Learn more →

Blue Chip

A nationally recognized, well-established, and financially sound company.

Learn more →

Blue-Chip Stock

Stock of a large, well-established and financially stable company.

Learn more →

Bond

A debt instrument that pays interest until maturity, when the face value is repaid.

Learn more →

Bond Covenant

A legally binding term of agreement between a bond issuer and a bondholder.

Learn more →

Bond Discount

The amount by which a bond's market price is lower than its face value.

Learn more →

Bond Equivalent Yield (BEY)

An annualized yield calculation of a discount bond.

Learn more →

Bond ETF

An exchange-traded fund investing in bonds.

Learn more →

Bond Fund

A fund that invests in bonds or other debt securities.

Learn more →

Bond Ladder

A portfolio of bonds with different maturity dates.

Learn more →

Bond Market

A financial market where participants can buy and sell debt securities.

Learn more →

Bond Quote

The last price at which a bond traded.

Learn more →

Bond Rating

A grade given to a bond that indicates its credit quality.

Learn more →

Bond Valuation

The process of determining the fair market value of a bond.

Learn more →

Bond Yield

The annual interest received from a bond as a percentage of its price.

Learn more →

Bonus Depreciation

An additional amount of deductible depreciation.

Learn more →

Bonus Issue

Free additional shares given to existing shareholders.

Learn more →

Book Building

A process used by underwriters to determine the price at which to offer an issue.

Learn more →

Book-to-Market Ratio

A ratio used to find the value of a company by comparing its book value to its market value.

Learn more →

Book Value

The value of an asset as it appears on a balance sheet.

Learn more →

Book Value of Equity Per Share (BVPS)

The equity available to common shareholders divided by the number of outstanding shares.

Learn more →

Borrowing Base

A method lenders use to determine how much to lend to a company based on its assets.

Learn more →

Bottom Line

A company's net earnings or losses.

Learn more →

Bottom-Up Investing

An investment approach focusing on the analysis of individual stocks.

Learn more →

Bounced Check

A check that cannot be processed because the writer has insufficient funds.

Learn more →

Branch Accounting

A system of accounting where separate accounts are maintained for each branch.

Learn more →

Branch Banking

A banking system where banks are permitted to operate multiple branches.

Learn more →

Breadth Indicator

A mathematical formula that uses the number of advancing and declining stocks to gauge market sentiment.

Learn more →

Bretton Woods Agreement and System

An international monetary system that established fixed foreign exchange rates.

Learn more →

Bridge Loan

A short-term loan that provides immediate cash flow until longer-term financing is secured.

Learn more →

Budget Deficit

A status of financial health in which expenditures exceed revenue.

Learn more →

Budget Surplus

A period when income or receipts exceed outlays or expenditures.

Learn more →

Budget Variance

The difference between the budgeted or baseline amount of expense or revenue.

Learn more →

Build America Bonds (BABs)

Taxable municipal bonds that carry special tax credits and federal subsidies.

Learn more →

Bull Call Spread

An options strategy designed to profit from a moderate rise in the price of an asset.

Learn more →

Bull Market

A market characterized by rising prices for securities.

Learn more →

Bull Trap

A false market signal where the declining trend of an asset appears to reverse but does not.

Learn more →

Bullet Bond

A bond that repays the entire principal amount at its maturity date.

Learn more →

Bullet Repayment

A one-time lump sum payment at the end of a loan's term.

Learn more →

Burn Rate

The rate at which a company is losing money.

Learn more →

Buy and Hold

An investment strategy focusing on long-term holding of assets.

Learn more →

Buy-In

The purchase of a controlling interest in a company.

Learn more →

Buy-Side

The side of the financial market that buys investment services.

Learn more →

Buy Stop Order

An order to buy a security once it reaches a specific price.

Learn more →

Buy the Dips

A strategy of buying after a decline in prices.

Learn more →

Buy to Cover

An order to buy a security to close a short position.

Learn more →

Buyback

The repurchase of shares by a company.

Learn more →

Buying on Margin

Borrowing money to buy securities.

C

C Corporation

A type of corporation taxed separately from its owners.

Call

An option to buy assets at a fixed price before a specific date.

Callable Bond

A bond that can be redeemed by the issuer before maturity.

Learn more →

Canceled Check

A check that has been paid or voided.

Learn more →

CAPE Ratio

A valuation measure using inflation-adjusted earnings over 10 years.

Learn more →

Capital Account

A national account reflecting capital transactions.

Learn more →

Capital Adequacy Ratio (CAR)

A measure of a bank's capital to its risk.

Learn more →

Capital Asset

A long-term asset that is not sold in the normal business course.

Learn more →

Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM)

A model for pricing an individual security or portfolio.

Learn more →

Capital Budgeting

The process of planning investments in long-term assets.

Learn more →

Capital Expenditure

Funds spent to acquire or upgrade physical assets.

Learn more →

Capital Gain

Profit from the sale of an investment.

Learn more →

Capital Gains Tax

Tax on profits from the sale of capital assets.

Learn more →

Capital Loss Carryover

Using capital losses that exceed capital gains to offset future gains.

Learn more →

Capital Market Line (CML)

A graphical representation of the capital asset pricing model.

Learn more →

Capital Markets

Financial markets for buying and selling long-term debt or equity-backed securities.

Learn more →

Capital Stock

The common and preferred stock a company is authorized to issue.

Capitalization

The total market value of a company's outstanding shares.

Capitalized Cost

A company expense that is added to the value of an asset.

Capitalized Interest

Interest added to the principal balance of a loan.

Carding

Unauthorized use of credit card information.

Carried Interest

A share of profits paid to the general partner in an investment fund.

Cash Accounting

Cash Budget

Cash Dividend

A payment of profits to company shareholders.

Cash Equivalents

Short-term investments easily convertible to cash.

Learn more →

Cash Flow

The net amount of cash moving in and out of a business.

Cash Flow from Financing Activities (CFF)

A section of a cash flow statement showing financing activities.

Learn more →

Cash Flow from Investing Activities

Cash spent or received from investments.

Cash Flow Statement

A financial statement showing cash inflows and outflows.

Cash-Out Refinance

Refinancing a mortgage for more than owed and taking the difference in cash.

Certificate of Deposit (CD)

A time deposit with a fixed maturity date and interest rate.

Chapter 11 Bankruptcy

A form of bankruptcy allowing a business to continue operations while reorganizing.

Clawback

A provision for recouping money, such as executive bonuses.

Closed-End Fund

Collateralized Loan Obligation (CLO)

A security backed by a pool of debt, often loans.

Combined Loan-To-Value Ratio (CLTV Ratio)

Combined Ratio

An insurer's incurred losses and expenses to earned premiums.

Commercial Loan

A loan granted to a business.

Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR)

The mean annual growth rate over time.

Consumer Credit

A debt that a person incurs for purchasing goods or services.
